On August 25, Prince Andrew lay leaning on his elbow in a broken-down shed in the village of Knyazkóvo.
The shed was at the further end of Prince Andrew’s regiment’s encampment.
Through a gap in the broken wall Prince Andrew could see beside the wooden fence a row of thirty-year-old birches with lower branches lopped off.
Prince Andrew could see a field on which shocks of oats were standing.
Prince Andrew could see some bushes near which rose the smoke of campfires.
The smoke of campfires came from the soldiers’ kitchens.
Prince Andrew felt his life was narrow, burdensome, and useless.
